body.p: In the previous module, we introduced probability as way to mathematically describe uncertainty. We saw that the probability of an event is estimated by the relative frequency with which an event occurs in a long series of trials.
In this module, we will shift our investigation to describing the probabilities of all possible outcomes, instead of the probability of just one outcome.

We can think of all the possible outcomes as variable values to which we are assigning probabilities. The variable values, together with the assigned probabilities, make up a probability distribution. Here is an example of a probability distribution.

example.p: Consider the variable “blood type.” This is a categorical variable with variable values A, B, AB, or O. Using relative frequencies from large samples of randomly chosen individuals, we can estimate the probability of choosing a person with a given blood type. body.p: Probability distributions for categorical variables, like in the example above, will not be investigated in this module. Instead, the focus of this module will be on probability distributions for quantitative variables, because such distributions will be used in statistical inference. Examples of such variables are “number of times a college student changes major” or “weight of a student.”

When the outcomes are quantitative, we call the variable a random variable. In this module, we discuss the probability distributions of Discrete Random Variables and Continuous Random Variables. Discrete random variables have values that can be listed and often can be counted. Continuous random variables can take any value in an interval and are often measurements. For example, the variable “number of times a college student changes major” is a discrete random variable. The (exact) weight of a person is a continuous random variable.

Comment: The word “random” here means that the outcomes are uncertain in the short run but have a regular distribution or predictable pattern in the long run. In statistics, we reserve the term “random variable” for quantitative variables. This can be a bit confusing, since categorical variables can also describe random outcomes.
Now we will investigate the probability distributions for discrete random variables.
